description: From Middle English sliten, from Old English slītan (“to slit, tear, rend, shiver, split, rend to pieces, cleave, divide”), from Proto-West Germanic *slītan, from Proto-Germanic *slītaną (“to tear”), from Proto-Indo-European *skleyd-, *(s)kelH- (“to cut, trim”).
Cognate with North Frisian slitten (“to clear, make void”), Dutch slijten (“to wear, waste, ravel out”), German schleißen (“to trim”), Swedish slita (“to rip, tear”). Doublet of slit. More at slice.

entries.meaning: (dialectal) The act or process of ripping up; rending; wear and tear.

verbs.description: slite (third-person singular simple present slites, present participle sliting, simple past slit or slited, past participle slit or slitten or slited)

entries.meaning: (transitive, dialectal) To slit; tear or rip up.
